results.title: The Genie from downunder. - Vol. 6.
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Jeremy Swan and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: In “Triple treat”, confusion reigns supreme when Conrad and Otto make two replica’s of Penelope’s magic opal. There’s lots of opal rubbing but little magic as a result! Bruce finally gets the opal back to the cave in “It’s still magic” and is about to free himself when Penelope and Baz accuse him of selfishness. Eventually some sort of compromise is reached and Bruce finds out about the magic of romance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Jeremy Swan and Esben Storm

results.title: The Genie from downunder. - Vol. 5.
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Jeremy Swan and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: In a ‘Tale of two cities’, Conrad works out that Bruce and Baz are genies and tries to learn more about their secret powers. In ‘School daze’ Penelope wishes herself back in England to avoid having to go to school in Australia and finds that she has to sit a “catch up” exam at her school when she returns.

results.title: The Genie from downunder. - Vol. 4.
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Brendan Maher and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: Another two exciting episodes in this excellent series for children. In ‘Nobody’s perfect’, in an effort to stop Bruce from misinterpreting her wishes, Penelope writes down her perfect wish. In ‘Triple agent’, Conrad is convinced that Bruce may be a vampire or cyborg and tries to catch him out.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, Brendan Maher and Esben Storm

results.title: The Genie from downunder. - Vol. 1.
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar and Phil Jones
results.brief_description: From the producers of “Round the twist” and “Skytrackers” comes a series about a young girl, Penelope Townes who finds a magic opal which contains two genies, Bruce and his son Baz. She thinks all her problems are over, and that she can have everything she wants. Bruce, however has other ideas. The first three episodes of this series are: “Wishing and hoping”, “It’s my opal…and I’ll cry if I want to” and Where it’s at.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Patricia Edgar and Phil Jones

results.title: The Genetic takeover
results.creator_credit: Eric Michel, ONF | NFB, Karl Parent and Louise Vandelac
results.brief_description: In just a few short years, genetically modified plants have become part of our daily diet and are already found in 75% of processed foods. This revolution has occurred without consumer awareness and without the knowledge of potential risks to our health and the environment. In response to consumer demands, many European and Asian countries have instituted mandatory labelling of genetically modified foods. North America and Canada however, have been slow to react. This video takes a sober look at a potentially explosive situation. It investigates the issue that industrial giants are willing to ignore basic safety rules in their relentless fight for profits and asks the question: Can food crops, a vital element of the collective wealth of this planet, remain at the mercy of private interests?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric Michel, ONF | NFB, Karl Parent and Louise Vandelac

results.title: The Genetic chance
results.creator_credit: Robert Reid and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “My Children My Children”.
Examines the moral and social implications of determining genetic disorders in unborn infants, and looks at the effects of a number of such disorders. Most of the discussion is centred around haemophilia.

results.title: The Genesis of a dissident
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet Government and Politics”.
One of a series of films which make up a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science Open University. Offers an introduction to contemporary Soviet politics whilst simultaneously relating political practice to the historical development of the Soviet State and Marxist political theory. Presented by Victor Fainberg.

results.title: The General. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Film Classics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited version of Clyde Bruckman and Buster Keaton’s 1926 comedy feature, showing Buster Keaton in his most successful period as an actor and director of this satire on Civil War espionage. Combines good examples of Keaton’s dry wit and acute sense of timing. This edited work, narrated by Paul Killiam, indicates the significance of ‘The General’ in film history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Film Classics
